video.title: Native Android App Tutorial: WhatsApp Clone
video.description:
Learn to build a full WhatsApp clone as a native android app using Android Studio, Firebase, Java, and Genymotion. This complete course for beginners takes you from start to finish.

💻Code - https://github.com/SimCoderYoutube/WhatsAppClone

⭐️Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:04:28) Setting Up the Project
⌨️ (0:08:20) Phone Number Authentication
⌨️ (0:33:12) Getting Ready to Display Contacts
⌨️ (0:58:11) Getting Contact List
⌨️ (1:08:18) Checking If Contact is Also an User
⌨️ (1:39:25) Display User's Name
⌨️ (1:44:36) Create an Unique Chat
⌨️ (2:09:56) Starting Chat Activity
⌨️ (2:24:03) Send a Message
⌨️ (2:39:51) Displaying Messages
⌨️ (2:49:53) Choose Media To Send
⌨️ (3:19:10) Sending Media
⌨️ (3:40:11) Displaying Media Messages
⌨️ (3:54:05) Sending Notifications
⌨️ (4:13:54) Sending Notifications to Chat Users
⌨️ (4:51:33) Multiple User Chat Room

Course developed by SimCoder. Check out the SimCoder YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQ5xY26cw5Noh6poIE-VBog
SimCoder website: http://www.simcoder.com

⭐️Links ⭐️
🔗 Glide - https://github.com/bumptech/glide
🔗 FrescoImageViewer - https://github.com/stfalcon-studio/FrescoImageViewer
🔗 OneSignal- https://onesignal.com/

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

replies.author: You Tube
replies.text: @Bina Prajapati , The kernel of windows is written in C, the kernel of Linux is written in C, the kernel of the android is a transferred Linux kernel. Why is the native for Android suddenly Java? More like a joke.

replies.author: Bina Prajapati
replies.text:
C++ is native for windows, and for android native is java
hybrid is flutter, xamarin, react native, etc

topLevelComment.author: Infinity Makerspace
topLevelComment.text: I am not impressed with this tutorial.  The presenter uses keyboard shortcuts without explaining what he is doing "lets clean this up, clickity click" and then code changes or does not match.  another error is where is stated that you need to change versions of dependencies that failed I had to use the latest, further more, Android studio have had an update where you do not have to add certain depencenies.  I feel @freeCodeCamp should pull tutorials if major changes to a platform/sdk have been released as this causes issues with people who wants to learn but now have to battle with modules etc not working and creating what is known as Training Scars.

topLevelComment.text: At 9:24, I can't download the firebase core dependency. Firebase's website says "You no longer need to add the Android library com.google.firebase:firebase-core. This SDK included the Firebase SDK for Google Analytics. Now, to use Analytics (or any of the Firebase products that require or recommend the use of Analytics), you need to explicitly add the Analytics dependency: com.google.firebase:firebase-analytics:17.2.1." I tried using the other dependency, but it gave me no luck.

replies.author: Anderson MV
replies.text:
Well, I almost finished the application and started last week, still working fine.



apply plugin: 'com.android.application'


android {
    compileSdkVersion 29
    buildToolsVersion "29.0.2"
    defaultConfig {
        applicationId "com.example.chat_app"
        minSdkVersion 18
        targetSdkVersion 29
        versionCode 1
        versionName "1.0"
        testInstrumentationRunner "androidx.test.runner.AndroidJUnitRunner"
    }
    buildTypes {
        release {
            minifyEnabled false
            proguardFiles getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android-optimize.txt'), 'proguard-rules.pro'
        }
    }
}


dependencies {
    implementation fileTree(dir: 'libs', include: ['*.jar'])
t    implementation 'androidx.appcompat:appcompat:1.1.0'
    implementation 'androidx.constraintlayout:constraintlayout:1.1.3'
    implementation 'com.android.support:design:29.0.0'


    implementation 'com.google.firebase:firebase-analytics:17.2.1'
    implementation 'com.google.firebase:firebase-storage:19.1.0'
    implementation 'com.google.firebase:firebase-database:19.2.0'
    implementation 'com.google.firebase:firebase-auth:19.2.0'


    implementation 'com.google.android.material:material:1.0.0'


    implementation 'com.github.bumptech.glide:glide:4.10.0'
    annotationProcessor 'com.github.bumptech.glide:compiler:4.10.0'


    implementation 'com.facebook.fresco:fresco:2.0.0'
    implementation 'com.github.stfalcon:frescoimageviewer:0.5.0'




    testImplementation 'junit:junit:4.12'
    androidTestImplementation 'androidx.test.ext:junit:1.1.1'
    androidTestImplementation 'androidx.test.espresso:espresso-core:3.2.0'
}


apply plugin: 'com.google.gms.google-services'

topLevelComment.author: ButterCup
topLevelComment.text: This is not a tutorial - its a pure walk-through. A tutorial should include at least basic explentation on what u doing and why. But this guy is just rambling on with concepts that he assumes the viewer already knows. Anyone who tries to learn android-development, i strongly disadvise you to use this as a way to learn it. This will only result you building an application which you have no idea what it really does or how it functions. Good luck and good bye.

replies.author: Errick Bolton
replies.text:
I would recommend Udacity. The course I'm currently taking is free and teaches you what you'd expect from a structured, paid course, starting with the basics. 

If anyone starts with no programming experience, like myself, I would strongly suggest their Android Basics course. You'd be taught everything from the user interface to multiple screen apps and networking. If you have some experience with Java, perhaps it's a good idea to browse their more advanced courses. Their basics course is split into 5 sub-courses.

I assume some would be wondering if I was paid to "promote" Udacity. Nope, I'm just some unemployed 25 year old trying to keep up with technological growth and advancements. After browsing online, I'm pleased to say that Udacity has helped a great deal more than most free courses I've seen. 

This video is great for those wanting to see an example of an app being built along with being shown how separate bits of code interact with one another.

Regards
Errick
